pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:6.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:6.2: At that time the nun Caṇḍakāḷī quarreled with the nuns, and then cried after repeatedly beating herself.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:6.3: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:6.5: “How can Venerable Caṇḍakāḷī cry after repeatedly beating herself?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:6.6: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Caṇḍakāḷī did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:6.9: How can the nun Caṇḍakāḷī cry after repeatedly beating herself?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:6.10: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:6.11: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:7.1: ‘If a nun cries after repeatedly beating herself, she commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:8.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Orders through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:9.3: If she cries after repeatedly beating herself, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:9.4: If she beats herself, but does not cry, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:9.5: If she cries, but does not beat herself, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20:10.2: if she is the first offender.
